comments:
In this course, students explore current topics in thermodynamics through
molecular simulations and molecular modeling. The requisite statistical mechanics are
conveyed as well as the essential simulation techniques (molecular dynamics, Monte
Carlo, etc.). Various approaches for calculating experimentally measurable properties are
presented and used in student projects.
Students found this course to be “useful” and “learned a lot” throughout the
semester. Some even expressed that they especially enjoyed hearing about the more
advanced topics in the course.
Students felt that Professor Riggleman did a great job of preparing assignments
that helped them utilize concepts learned in class, emphasizing their thinking and
problem-solving skills.
Overall, students felt that the class was graded generously and that exams were a
fair assessment of knowledge. This course was recommended for both majors and nonmajors
who are interested in the topic. However, it was also recommended that students
should have some programming background before taking this class. The official
prerequisites for this course are CBE 231 or 618, or any other equivalent background in
physical chemistry.
